reviewText:
First of all this game falls into the category of oldies, for me.  I found a strategy guide dated 2012 when I was looking for the original publishing date which I did not find.  Since I am fool for old school I like it, of course.  Old school games are hidden object driven and with no time limits, no misclick penalties and no penalties for hints. (Hints are expected and a lot of hint use is normal.) There is no map or achievements (in-game and definitely not Steam).  All these things simply do not exist in this game.  The storyline is simple, very simple. (Some fairy tales are more complex.)  This game is also more or less open world, and the gamer has the freedom to chose what to do and do it in whatever order they want.  The game is not linear, it progresses.

Story: A paranormal investigator has been called to the town of Deadwood to free them (the town) from the vengeful and murderous ghost of the infamous gun man Blackjack.  In life Blackjack killed 21 men, in death he killed many more.  How does one save an entire town and all its residents from a vengeful ghost?  Break the curse, of course.  Oh and a long the way meet all the resident ghosts which are conjured up by the investigator's psychic gift of seeing and talking to the dead.

Gameplay:  As I said before this is old school with just a bit of that point and click element of picking up inventory items as the gamer goes by.  This game is Hidden Object scene driven.  The Hidden Object finds are drawn in, not overlayed, making some of the find clues uniquely intesting when one sees the whole" thing.  Many of the find clues are very fragmented and nearly unrecognizable after they have been found and the gamer can see them.  Just thought I would mention that.

Some reviewers have complained about clicking on some of the objects which do not seem to be obtainable until clicking all over the find object.  I am not going to say this does not happen
recommended: I would also like to point out a quite clever thing the developers did with the Hidden Object scenes.  The Hidden Object scenes break down into three types: straight find clue lists (no fragmented or extra hidden places to look in)
hoursPlayed: find X amount of objects and silhouettes.  The X amount of objects are straight forward and very easy.  A fast clicker can probably complete these in about ten seconds.  The straight find list have some well hidden finds
helpfulPercent: but are easy enough.  Neither of these types have the above mentioned "issue/problem" of having to hit just the right spot either.  However
votesHelpful: the silhouettes in some cases do.  I believe that is because the developers did something quite clever with the silhouette scenes.  A general silhouette find for most players goes like this
votesTotal: see the silhouette then click on that object in the hidden object scene.  And I believe most people played exactly that way.  Yet what these developers did was make the silhouettes MOVEABLE so they CAN BE PICKED AND PLACED OVER THE FIND OBJECT IN THE PUZZLE SCENE.  The silhouettes actually lie on top of other another and can be moved around in the clue box
votesFunny: as well.  So the silhouette hidden object puzzles can actually be played either way
commentsCount: locate the find object in the puzzle scene and click on it
column16: or move the silhouette on top of the find object.  Some of the very obscured find objects are very hard to click on and to find the right spot
column17: but if the silhouette is laid on top of it
column19: find clue completed.  I found this quite fun once I realized that this happened.  Very clever.\n\nPuzzles:  This game has real puzzles
column20: and I do mean that literally.  Put the pieces in place
column21: whether the pieces are rectangles or circles
column22: to form a picture.  One clever type of puzzle is matching the puzzle piece to the picture that has been divided up in mini-hexagons like a beehive.  There are not many puzzles in comparison to the hidden object scenes
column23: and they are usually found on doors or pictures or some "locked" place.\n\nThis is a relatively short game
column25: but enjoyable nonetheless.\n\nJust a few words on music
column27: and voice acting which I seldom ever comment on.  The music is repetitive but fitting
column28: though maybe it is just me but some pieces seemed louder then others
column29: since I found myself adjusting the volume from scene to scene.  Art work is very stylized and quite typical of the art style when this game was first published.  Voice acting .... hmmm...  The undertaker's voice was as annoying as his character
column30: so the voice acting was "spot" on
column31: even if I did not like it.  The voices in general fit the characters
column32:
though I think they tended more toward Southern accents instead of Western ones.

Overall an interesting game to play with quite different game elements and puzzles then those found today.

Oh one last thing I am unsure why this is a collector's edition.  There are no extras
column34: no extra chapter and no strategy guide that one usually associates with collector's editions."

reviewText:
TL;DR: Bad hitbox in minigames, unchallenging puzzles, story lacks depth and the game is illogical.
Reasoning:
NB! I played the game on the hard mode.

-The story in itself is horrible and lacks depth, but that is okay, cause it is just a 'hidden object game', and I do not expect an in-depth story any more. It is as if the genre itself is lacking that final push to become more modern. This particulary story left me very unsatisfied, and I was not ready for 'the end'.
-The puzzles are also quiet bad and not very challenging, having few types. Most of them is about matching a puzzlepiece to a screen, but the shadows makes it obvious.

These two I can live with, but the worst is still to be written:

-The hitbox within the HIDDEN OBJECT mini-games are NOT MATCHING WITH THE CLICKABLE ITEM! However, there is also no penalty from clicking fast over the entire screen. The items are also reused a lot, having the same bowl with the same items in, in almost every scene. Those are not the clickable items, but it makes it easier to look past - you simply know that you're not searching for it.
-The game lacks LOGIC! If you need, lets say, a hammer, you cannot take any hammer - you need THE hammer. I realize that this occurs in other games, and I've played a lot of hidden object games over the years, but this is by far the worst.

I also had no horrorfeeling what so ever, and I believe it is because of the lack of suspense. Also, many games become more horror-like if you can actually be harmed.
voteText: 13 of 16 people (81%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Riddled with basic technical errors, such as silhouettes in a list overlapping each other so you can hardly tell what you're supposed to find, and items in a hidden object scene not registering as found unless you click in precisely the right place. The highlight was one HO scene with a belt arranged in a loop, which was not only half hidden behind the interface, but the game wouldn't accept that I found it until I clicked the empty space in the middle of the loop.

Might be forgiveable if the rest of the game was good, but the story is bland and the puzzles are incredibly lazy. A lot of them involve finding the pieces of a lock, and then suddenly the lock turns into a really bad jigsaw puzzle and you have to put the pieces together, because anything more complicated would be too difficult to program, or something.

I played the whole thing (about 2 hours long) because I apparently have no better outlet for my newfound masochistic tendencies. Don't be like me.
voteText: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Short version: 70%Ghost Encounters is a pretty standard hidden object game set in a dead Western town. It may not win awards with its writing, but its many good hidden object scenes certainly should put it on the map of any HOG fan.

Long version:After playing through Ghost Encounters: Deadwood, I’m somewhat baffled by the abysmal Steam ratings. Sure, this hidden object game isn’t a masterpiece, but it is far from being bad.

The story has a fairly average premise: a paranormal investigator decides to get to the bottom of the curse of a desolate Western town hunted by a vengeful spirit of an outlaw. What she sees there though is anything but a predictable HOG story. Nothing ground-breaking, and the voice-acting is rather mediocre, but it has its own moments and even a few well-written surprises.

Gameplay is simple and the puzzles quickly get repetitive, probably this is why we get tons of hidden object scenes instead. As a feature presentation, they work great: the scenes are crowded, but only to the point to be fair in their challenge. In my book, this aspect alone should earn Ghost Encounters a spot in most HOG fans’ libraries.

While there are some minor technical difficulties, i.e. a few objects in the HO scenes took some pixel-hunting to obtain), nothing is off-the-charts bad.  There were honestly so few of the why is it taking me 150029492 clicks to get this object" problems

The game ran perfectly on my newish Windows 10 laptop.  No issues whatsover.

Graphically a little older-looking but still nice-looking.   Voice-acting was decent which is all I've learned to want in a HO game.  Music and sound was well done.

There are not a lot of frills to this game; no interactive map

reviewText:
It took me 2.6 hours to finish this game in +hints mode. It's a traditional point and click adventure with a horror setting.
In this game to make progress in story mode you will have to go through some mini puzzle games like, find the objects, match the objects, match the broken pieces etc and sometimes this puzzle games can be very tiring and repetitive. Like all other point and click adventure game you will have to collect the right item and use it for the right situation. There is nothing new.
Story is not that good and voice acting is so-so. But, background music is good. This game's music will give you the horror feeling and it matches with the game perfectly.

In the end I kinda enjoyed this game in my own way. I think its a good puzzle/educational game for kids and they will definitely enjoy this game. To be honest the current price for this game is kinda high. But, buy this game if its for your kid or in sale or in bundle.

reviewText:
Temporary Review
First and foremost this is a impression review, and kind of a rant too.

I tried to start this game, a question in the forum wasn't answered and the websites given by the developers and other resources gave no viable resolution to the troubles the game was causing.

I could see the intro movie, it ran quite laggy - I could also see the startup screen and enter my screenname, but that's all I was able to. Because as soon as you press Play the game crashes, I tried all the regular stuff to fix and patch it, but nothing, really nothing worked. Neither looking up the newest drivers of my Video card, neither updating Flash, Shockwave and other things, not even installing it on another harddrive did work... the game seems to have serious troubles with running correctly. It crashes almost instantly.

This is, of course not a reason to recommend the game and thus I vote for:

Not Recommended
Because of bad user support, general (often not working) links to get the game running.

I will change this review as soon as I get the game started alongside with the solution to the troubleshooting.

Addendum as per 09 September 2015
I have litterally given up on the game and on the support. So this game will end up in the broken for good section of my library, probably to be never tried again.

reviewText:
So a hidden object game, and if you know the genre you probably know what to expect more or less - the story is fairly perfunctory, the few animations of characters are bad, the hidden object scenes are decent if overused, the in game logic is as random as nearly all such games - one minute you are psychically picking up and keeping items you have no idea you need yet (at least in this case you could argue some slight justification in the story for this), the next you seem to have thrown away the last 15-20 hammers you have picked up during the story so far and now need another one, etc.

The main good points here are that the graphics are pretty decent, none of the scenes will really have you squinting to try and determine what something is, the point and click segments mostly make sense and flow from each other without having to backtrack too much.

The weaker points are the lack of a map and the hint system is very general (it tells you what you need to do next accurately, but it isn't always obvious where you have to go or where to find an item it says you need) - the lack of map isn't too bad though, as the game is fairly linear and you tend to mostly work in one area at a time, and it does have the plus of making it slightly more immersive than in other games in the genre where you just end up teleporting around chasing exclamation marks. The mini game puzzles are also very easy pretty much across the board, so don't expect to really stretch your brain here.

It is perfectly playable (and currently ridiculously cheap), so if you want another HOG then this is a perfectly acceptable option if you aren't too picky.

reviewText:
Before I get too far into a review, this game is a perfect example of why we should have a neutral option for recommendations. I more or less enjoyed it, but it has plenty of drawbacks that some people might consider deal breakers.  It wasnt bad, but it wasnt great either. If it sounds interesting, grab it on a discount, but I wouldnt pay full price.

The game is very buggy. For me, nothing was voiced until I clicked the characters a second time, and then the voice audio would ignore all volume settings. Not game breaking, but very annoying. Clicking objects in the puzzles wasnt an exact science either. You had to click them just right to get it to register that you found the item, and more than once I sat there spam clicking an object until the game registered that I found it.

Story wasnt too bad, but it was pretty predictable. I wont spoil it, but I figured out the twist" pretty early on. Was a bit hard for me to feel involved in the story
date:
but it was interesting enough for me to want to finish the game and see the ending.

Puzzles were pretty easy and repeated a couple times.

In the end
recommended: the game is a very basic hidden object game with its fair share of bugs. It isnt terrible
hoursPlayed: but it certainly isnt that great. It was a nice
helpfulPercent: relaxing playthrough though. Decent grab if you catch it on discount or find it in a bundle."

reviewText:
This game has some decent hidden-object scenes.

Otherwise, it's quite bad. The story, script, voice acting, and puzzles are very mediocre.

There is no map, so you will have to constantly backtrack for the humdrum point-and-click adventuring.

The game engine is buggy: sometimes you click where you're supposed to and nothing happens, even in hidden-object scenes, and sound will repeat itself before finishing if you click on something more than once.

reviewText: Not a bad little game at all. Worth picking up if you're looking for something to do for an hour or two.

While the story of this game is ok, as are the graphics I can´t recommend it for a number of reasons:

1) The hitboxes in the hidden object puzzles are simply bad

2) The hidden object puzzles themselves vary from decent to downright awful, an example of the latter would be finding 12 rolls of ducttape pasted onto a previous hidden object scene

3) The german translation is simply unfit for purpose as it is complete gibberish at times, and as there is no way i could find to turn the game pack to english even though my steam client is set to english it made the game almost unplayable,

In short, there are many, many better hidden object games out there, don´t buy this one.

And for my countrymen the most important part again in german:

Übersetzung ist furchtbar, daher sind oftmals nichtmal die Hilfe Texte zu verstehen und das macht das Spiel beinahe unspielbar.

(and just in case the english speakers among you wonder here is a translation of that german sentence)

Translation is awful, because of this even the help text is impossible to understant at times, this makes the game almost unplayable.

Decent story, but too short. Also, some of the hidden object scenes were quite frustrating because often the objects wouldn't register, even if you clicked on them several times. Took a lot of patience.

As Hidden Object games go, this one is pretty boring. It seems lazy once you start doing the Hidden Object mini-games, the cutouts are bad on the object and the Hit Box is really off. But the absolutely worst offence is that the villain is not scary og mystical, he's just boring and feels un-necessary.\n\nBut it's cheap and I did manage to play through the whole game and I'm glad I did. If you are into boring HOG's then give it a go, otherwise there are so many better and involving games out there.
It's not bad, but it's not particularly good either. I also don't see what is 'Collector's Edition' about it. Fine for £1 or so and a couple of hours but, I suspect, imminently forgettable.

All in all, it's a decent HOG.  The puzzles are not hard, and you can figure out most things by yourself.  I did experience some of the hit box issues others have mentioned.  First, it was mostly objects in my upper right screen (no idea why).  Second, I found you can (and in some cases HAVE to) hit the empty" area in the center of the object like a necklace or belt rather than trying to click on the object itself.  I also experienced a glitch in the last part of the game where I could not go anywhere
date: but closing out the game completely and opening it back up fixed that
recommended: and I was able to complete the game."

reviewText:
I beat this game in a 3.2 hourss (possibly less if I could figure out what they wanted me to do next).  The puzzles a mild brain teasers and they story seems sparcely put together.  Some of the hunting around for items is a little disconnected.  Not sure if I can honestly recommend this game, I am not really certain I understand why Blackjack was ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off, just knew he was killing the whole town and thats it.....I just felt more could be put into the story and in the puzzles. Graphics are on the line of similar hunt and pecks, so its got that going for it.  The searchables were a little broken and I dare someone to truly try to play this game without using a hint, let alone find the gate in the back of the graveyard.

I am willing to change my view if the designers decide to revisit this game and give it more of a story and a little more understanding of what need to happen.

Good game, fun story line.
You play a paranormal detective called to save a boy from the grasp of a evil murdering ghost.
Only glitch was in some hidden object games, it was very difficult ti select the wanted objects. You had to click at the specific point on  or beside the wanted object for it to selected. Some of them took repeated clicks all over the object and around to finally get it, A little frustrating, when you can't skip anything and really need to finish the puzzle to continue.

Over all loved the game and recommend it, just keep the glitch in mind.

i give it 5/10

still worth playing if u get it off a bundle and u really like HOGs...

i recommend getting it off a bundle
i dont recommend it for the full price
Cool game. only 2 hours playtime. some minor translation failures to german and a few bugs on the clickboxes, but over all worth buying

Ok to start lets forget for a minute that there is no map. Now don't get me wrong I absolutly love Hidden Objsct Game, this is the worst one I have ever played. The hit dectection on some of the objest is absolutly horrible i spent 20 minutes trying to click on a lizard! I figured oh i must have the wrong item, used a hint nope right item just had to find that one pixel to click on! Some of the puzzels that they love to reuse are made my the devil himself. Also the hints are vague at best which will lead you to running around the whole map trying to find out where your suppose to place/use objects, which lead back to there is NO MAP! I spent more time running around trying to figure out what i was trying to do than doing things in this game! Now i went out of my way to finish this thing that at this point i refuse to call a game, it was more like a true test of endurance and patience, but if for some reason you just HAVE to play this game" use the walkthrough. Honestly though just save your money
date: getting it for free will make you feel ripped off."
